  Unit testing code that runs in a framework is not difficult, but it 
  can be annoying. This really merits an article, but here are the 
  bullet points.

  1. Identify the extension points where you write your code.
  2. In the extension points, identify the objects that you or the 
  framework use when executing your code.
  3. Change your code to accept those objects as parameters, either to 
  a constructor or its methods.
  4. Test the new code and either trust that the "glue code" will work 
  or refactor the glue code so that it is written only once. (Then you 
  can test it once.)

  For example, in Struts, you code an Action class by 
  overriding "execute()". Your code accesses your model and decides 
  which page to return as a response. Action.execute() takes 
  parameters to represent the Action list, an input form, the servlet 
  request and the servlet response. Typically, you will grab data from 
  the input form, set attributes on the request and specify the page 
  to forward to by name (a String).

  Therefore, I write a method like this:

  String doExecute(final MyModel model, final MyForm form, final Map 
  attributes) throws Exception {
      // grab form parameters from 'form'
      // talk to the model
      // add attributes to 'attributes'
      // return the name of the page to forward to (the "forward name")
  }

  I can easily create or mock MyModel and MyForm as well as the Map of 
  attributes. I can easily check that the resulting forward name is 
  correct. I unit test this method as much as possible. Then I write:

  ActionForward execute(final ActionMapping actionMapping, final 
  ActionForm form, final HttpServletRequest request, final 
  HttpServletResponse response) throws Exception {
      final MyForm myForm = (MyForm) form;
      final MyModel model = new MyModel();    // or retrieve from some 
  factory or creation method
      final Map attributes = new HashMap();
      
      final String forwardName = doExecute(myForm, model, attributes);
      setRequestAttributes(request, attributes);
      return actionMapping.findForward(forwardName);
  }

  The method setRequestAttributes simply iterates over the map entries 
  and calls request.setAttribute for each one.

  Notice that the glue code is quite boilerplate in nature. I could 
  even generate it or write it using funky reflection. This is a great 
  way to remove duplication.

  If I find that I need more stuff in my doExecute() method, like 
  another part of the request, I can create a narrow 
  interface "RequestProperties" and pass that in to 'doExecute'. In 
  the test code, I fake out the RequestProperties; in the production 
  code, I wrap the Request in another object that implements 
  RequestProperties. The goal is to improve substitutability of 
  implementation to maximize ease of testing.

  What do you think?

  --JBR.
